ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class used linguistics and cognitive science to investigate signed languages, drawing upon social, political, experimental, artistic, and cultural lenses to highlight what makes these languages unique and/or similar to spoken languages.
i learned an incredible amount about deaf culture and how languages function in the different modalities

I had the chance to learn about sign langauges from a historical, linguistic, cognitive, and sociological perspective. All of this served to dispell so many misconseptions I had about the Deaf community, which I hope to carry into my everday life. The final project also really helped with the general skill of formulating a research question and designing an experiment. This was more difficult than I expected but well worth it and I hope to continue improving in this area.
Through this course I learned a lot more about the linguistics of sign language and gained more perspective on the d/Deaf community

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is well-balanced in terms of breadth of topics, and well designed to keep students engaged and applying what they learn to their own work. The class also does well with depth, though sometimes the depth might be a lot to process or dive into initially. As the course progresses, the information builds on itself and connects well.
it was difficult to follow some of the more linguistic heavy materials.

We were very fortunate to have many interesting guest speakers, and that was one of the best parts of the course.
Overall, the structure of the course had a nice flow and went better than I expected through zoom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course worked well in a virtual format, as each week's seminar was a conversation. In fact, this class wouldn't have been what it was without the virtual format, as this allowed the class to be accessible to a variety of fascinating and informative guest speakers. Being able to engage with Deaf individuals who have their own relationships to the materials of the course made for an engaging class, and an incredible opportunity.
i found the course was successful given the circumstances

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this class to anyone who would like to know more about the cognitive and linguistic aspects of signed languages, and be able to take away knowledge of Deaf culture and engage in meaningful discussions about what it means to be part of a speech community.
yes, i found it very interesting
